Title:                                                                                              "Tariffs, Rising Prices, and Increasing Needs Causes Cost Effectiveness in Coins to Plummet."


Thoughts I have:


2008 financial crisis is shown in this graph, as an extreme rise and fall.

Penny is the least changing one and the lowest cost.

Nickel is losing the most money, maybe because of the material and its the greater need for it?

Even though penny is not being used nearly as much as the other coins, it is still unprofitable.

Nickel is losing more than 150% of its value.

Questions i have:

All of these coins are made mostly of copper, most of alloys of 75% copper and 25% nickel. Is the rising prices and needs of copper making the cost less effective?

As tariffs across the world get more and more, does this affect the output of cost effectiveness?

The U.S. trades with much of the world to gain these materials, such as rare earth metals (lanthanides) from mines in china. As the tariffs against these are raised, the need and cost of them grows. Similarly, are the materials for these coins (copper and nickel mainly) from foreign mines and sources rising because of these global tariffs?

name: Zachy g
comment info:
What I Notice
The cost to make U.S. coins has increased a lot since 2001. In 2024, it costs 3.7 cents to make a penny, 13.8 cents to make a nickel, 5.8 cents to make a dime, and 14.7 cents to make a quarter. That means pennies and nickels actually cost more to make than they’re worth. The rise is especially sharp for nickels and quarters.
What I Wonder
I wonder why the cost to produce coins has gone up so much—especially for nickels. Is it because of rising metal prices, inflation, or changes in manufacturing? I also wonder if the government might stop producing pennies or change the materials to save money.
How This Relates to Me and My Community
Coins are still used in daily life, like vending machines or parking meters. If it costs more to make them than they’re worth, the government could raise taxes or cut costs elsewhere. Also, if pennies or nickels disappear, it could affect how stores price items or give change in my community.
Catchy Headline
“It Costs More to Make Money: Pennies and Nickels Lose Their Value in Production”

name: Alex Tran
comment info:
What do you notice?
The cost to produce U.S. coins has increased significantly since 2001. In 2024, it costs more than the value to make the penny (3.7¢ to make 1¢) and the nickel (13.8¢ to make 5¢). The dime and quarter also cost more to produce than in past years, reaching 5.8¢ and 14.7¢.
What do you wonder?
I wonder why the cost of producing coins has risen so much? Is it because of higher metal prices, inflation, or manufacturing expenses? I also wonder if the U.S. Mint will stop producing pennies and nickels since they cost more to make than they’re worth.
How does this relate to you and your community?
In Vietnam, we don’t really use coins anymore, now people mostly use paper money or online payments. Seeing this makes me think about how coins can become less useful when they cost too much to make, and maybe countries like the U.S. should also remove the coin and use more digital money.
Catchy Headline:
“Making Money Is Losing Money”

replies.name: o

name: Vivien Huynh
comment info:
What do you Notice: While the manufacturing cost of pennies and nickels is more costly than their worth (especially for the nickels), the cost of dimes and quarters is much cheaper than their value.

What do you Wonder: While some countries (like Canada in 2013 as an example) stopped using their pennies as currency because they cost more than they worth, why is the US still producing currency that is more costly than their real value? If this situation still happens, are we losing our money significantly and unnecessarily? 

How does this Relate to you and your community: In my country, Vietnam, the National Government Bank stopped releasing coins as currency in 2011 and people exchanged their coins to paper money in local banks. The reasons behind the transition from using coins to paper money in Vietnam was preventing inflation (the value of coins was too low for current living costs), inconvenience (heavy, easily lost and prone to rust) and the scarcity of material (bronze, nickel). 

Catchy headline: Minting Millions, Losing Millions: The Absurdity of the Penny

Keep noticing and wondering!

name: Cayden N.
comment info:
I notice that the coins with lower values like the penny and the nickel have become not cost-effective to make, since the cost to produce them is greater than their value, whereas higher-valued coins like dimes and quarters are worth about twice as much as it costs to make them. It’s also interesting that nickels cost almost 15¢ to make (almost as much as the quarter) while being worth only 5¢. There is also a noticeable drop in the cost to produce coins around 2020 when the pandemic was happening. Based on the political and economic state of the world right now, it seems that the trend of increasing cost will only go up as we accrue more debt and inflation rises, but I wonder whether this will actually happen or if we’ll turn the economy around. I also wonder what will happen to prices as we phase out coins like the penny (and presumably the nickel later), since prices will be rounded up to the nearest 0.10¢ since pennies and nickels will no longer be in circulation. Alternatively, people will most likely start paying with card rather than cash in order to make sure that they only have to pay as much as they need. Since we’ll only have coins that pay themselves off, the government will save a lot of money and can use it for other things.

Why are Nickels Worth as Much as Quarters?

name: Charlie
comment info:
I notice that the penny and the nickel are quickly becoming more costly to produce than they are worth, with the nickel especially being far more expensive (almost matching the quarter). There also seems to be a dip around 2020 among all the coins, where they actually became cheaper instead of continuing the trend of increasing cost.

I wonder what the full graph for a longer time period would look like, and also whether the trend of phasing out coins (like the penny) will continue until we only use dollar bills.

This could cause prices to rise slightly for every product over time, as it would be illogical for prices to end in .99 if pennies are no longer in circulation, or for prices to end in .05, if nickels do not exist (and it is very unlikely that corporations—or anyone for that matter—would opt to round down their prices, rather than round up). Although the numbers are very small, they do add up over time given the amount of products the average consumer purchases. The middle-class and people with stable incomes likely won’t be as affected, since these people also generally pay with card rather than cash, but those less fortunate may have to create an even stricter budget to afford the most basic products. Another factor would also be the effect it has on taxpayer money, as phasing out coins that do not pay themselves off would save lots of money that could be redirected for more useful expenditures.

Will the Nickel follow the Penny?
